==Hungarian==

===Etymology===
From the obsolete dialectal {{m|hu|okik||to learn a lesson, to be edified}}, itself from a {{etyl|trk|hu}} language.<ref>{{R:Zaicz 2006}}</ref>

===Pronunciation===
* {{hu-IPA}}
* {{audio|Hu-ok.ogg|Audio|lang=hu}}

===Noun===
{{hu-noun|ok}}

# [[cause]]
# [[reason]]

====Declension====
{{hu-infl-nom|oko|o}}{{hu-pos-otok|ok||ai}}

====Derived terms====
* [[okmány]]
* [[okol]]
* [[okos]]
* [[okoz]]
* [[okság]]
* [[oktalan]]
* [[okvetlen]]
{{qualifier|Compound words}}:
* [[halálok]]
* [[okirat]]
* [[oklevél]]

* [[okít]]
* [[oktat]]
* [[okul]]

==Ido==
{{cardinalbox|io|7|8|9|sep|non|ord=okesma|adv=okfoye|mult=okopla|frac=okima|wplink=8_(nombro)}}

===Etymology===
From {{etyl|eo|io}} {{term|lang=eo|ok}}, from {{etyl|la|io}} {{term|octo|lang=la}}, ultimately from {{etyl|ine-pro|io}} {{m|ine-pro|*oḱtṓw}}.

{{head|io|numeral}}
# {{context|cardinal|lang=io}} [[eight]] (8)

==Old Norse==

===Etymology 1===
From {{inh|non|gem-pro|*auk||also}}. Cognate with {{etyl|ang|-}} {{m|ang|ēac}}, {{etyl|ofs|-}} {{term|āk|||lang=ofs}}, {{etyl|osx|-}} {{m|osx|ōk}}, {{etyl|goh|-}} {{term|ouh|lang=goh}}, {{etyl|got|-}} {{term|𐌰𐌿𐌺|lang=got}}.

====Conjunction====
{{head|non|conjunction}}

# [[and]]

=====Descendants=====
{{top2}}
* Danish: {{l|da|og}}
* Faroese: {{l|fo|og}}
* Icelandic: {{l|is|og}}
{{mid2}}
* Norwegian: {{l|no|og}}
* Swedish: {{l|sv|och}}
{{bottom}}

====Adverb====
{{head|non|adverb}}

# [[also]], [[too]]

===Etymology 2===
From {{inh|non|gem-pro|*juką}}, from {{etyl|ine-pro|non}} {{m|ine-pro|*yugóm}}.

====Noun====
{{non-noun|n|oks|ok}}

# [[yoke]]

=====Declension=====
{{non-decl-n-a|ok|ok}}

=====Descendants=====
{{top2}}
* Danish: {{l|da|åg}}
* Faroese: {{l|fo|ok}}
* Icelandic: {{l|is|ok}}
{{mid2}}
* Norwegian: {{l|no|åk}}
* Swedish: {{l|sv|ok}}
{{bottom}}

==Swedish==

===Etymology 1===
From {{etyl|non|sv}} {{term|ok|lang=non}}, from {{etyl|gem-pro|sv}} {{m|gem-pro|*juką}}, from {{etyl|ine-pro|sv}} {{m|ine-pro|*yugóm}}.

====Noun====
{{sv-noun|n}}

# [[yoke]]; a wooden bar used to connect two oxen by their shoulders
# yoke; a wooden bar to be placed over one's shoulders, and used to carry buckets
# heavy [[burden]]
# yoke; the part of a shirt draped over the wearer's shoulders

=====Declension=====
{{sv-infl-noun-n-zero}}

=====Related terms=====
* [[bromsok]]

====Etymology 2====

====Conjunction====
{{head|sv|conjunction}}
#{{alternative form of|och|lang=sv}}

====Adverb====
{{head|sv|adverb}}
#{{alternative form of|ock|lang=sv}}

* [[OK]]
